Specific Details: Ballina Chamber of Commerce requests support for Ballina Salmon Festival, including funding of the festival from the Failte Ire/Mayo Co Co Regional fund - from the Regional Festivals & Participative Events Programme 2020, administered by Mayo County Council.  Applications were open for festivals to apply for funding.  Ballina Salmon Festival, the longest runing community festival along the Wild Atlantic Way, would be in its 55th year, applied for funding.

Specific Details: Create a taskforce to tackle the derelection and high commercial vacancy rates in Ballina through colloboration with public, private and voluntary organisatons in Ballina, Co Mayo.
DPOs Lobbied: Tom Gilligan|Director of Services or Equivalent|Mayo County Council::Mark Duffy|Councillor|Mayo County Council
Subject Matter: Create a taskforce to tackle the derelection and high commercial vacancy rates in Ballina through colloboration with public, private and voluntary organisatons in Ballina, Co Mayo.
Intended Results: By creating a Derelection and Vacancy Taskforce, a core group can identify a series of actions needed to help reduce the high vacancy rates pravelient in town, identify buildings that have become derelect, and supported by local authority, voluntary groups on agreed key actions in order to address the high vacancy rates and falling vibrancy of Ballina Town. By identifying a series of actions needed over a 1-3 year period, the group would support town centre renewal, create new opportunities.
Lobbying Activities: Ballina derelection and vacancy taskforce comprises of Declan Turnbull and Robbie McGuire, Mayo Co Co, Ballina Chamber of Commerce,  Ballina Tidy Towns, Ballina Lions Cliub, Ballina Community Cleanup and plan on hosting a series of meetings, in order for short and long term actions and results be planned, so that results can bee seen, immediate action is imperative in order for short term gains with long term results.|Meeting|2-5
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Mags Martin, Ballina Chamber of Commerce

Specific Details: Ballina's Decarbonising Committee & Green Town Initiative presented to the Ballina Municipal District Council outlining the ambitions and strategic plans for the next five years; ensuring Ballina is Irelands Greenest town by 2025. With particular reference to preserving/protecting a green zone space in Ballina Town Centre; ensure the town centre space is landscaped and utilised as a green space for citizens and visitors to Ballina enjoy, rather than the preferred car park as laid down by Mayo Co
DPOs Lobbied: Mark Duffy|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Jarlath Munnelly|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Annie May Reape|Councillor|Mayo County Council::John O'Hara|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Seamus Weir|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Michael Loftus|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Tom Gilligan|Director of Services or Equivalent|Mayo County Council
Subject Matter: Ballina's Decarbonising Committee & Green Town Initiative presented to the Ballina Municipal District Council outlining the ambitions and strategic plans for the next five years; ensuring Ballina is Irelands Greenest town by 2025. With particular reference to preserving/protecting a green zone space in Ballina Town Centre; ensure the town centre space is landscaped and utilised as a green space for citizens and visitors to Ballina enjoy, rather than the preferred car park as laid down by Mayo Co
Intended Results: The Municipal are aware of the ambitions of the Decarbonisation Committe, plans for the future and in particular highlight the people of the town who signed the Blalina Green Town Charter
Lobbying Activities: A presentation was made on behalf of Ballina Decarbonisation Committee to the Municipal District Council Meeting, which also included Declan Turnbull, Head of Ballina Municipal, Mayo County Council, outlining the plans and ambitions of the group.|Meeting|2-5

Specific Details: Meter Changes - Irish Water
DPOs Lobbied: Al McDonnell|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Annie May Reape|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Blackie Gavin|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Brendan Mulroy|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Catherine McConnell|Director of Services or Equivalent|Mayo County Council::Christy Hyland|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Cyril Burke|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Damien Ryan|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Donna Sheridan|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Ger Deere|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Gerry Coyle|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Gerry Murray|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Jarlath Munnelly|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Joanne Grehan|Director of Services or Equivalent|Mayo County Council::John Caulfield|Councillor|Mayo County Council::John Condon|Director of Services or Equivalent|Mayo County Council::John Cribbin|Councillor|Mayo County Council::John O'Hara|Councillor|Mayo County Council::John O'Malley|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Kevin Kelly|Chief Executive Officer|Mayo County Council::Mark Duffy|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Martin McLoughlin|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Michael Burke|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Michael Kilcoyne|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Michael Loftus|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Michael Smyth|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Neil Cruise|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Patsy O'Brien|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Paul McNamara|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Peter Duggan|Head of Finance|Mayo County Council::Peter Flynn|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Richard Finn|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Seamus Weir|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Sean Carey|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Tom Connolly|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Tom Gilligan|Director of Services or Equivalent|Mayo County Council
Subject Matter: Meter Changes - Irish Water
Intended Results: To call on Irish Water to issue one single meter charge to replace the multiple meter charges that are currently in place.::To highlight that many farmers who have fragmented farms face multiple water meter charges which in some cases exceed the actual volumetric charge.::To highlight that IFA is seeking a meeting with the Commission for Regulation of Utilities (CRU), as we strongly dispute CRU's statement on their website that the new Non-Domestic Tariffs are fairer especially for farm customers.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Roy O'Brien IFA Regional Executive, Jarlath Walsh IFA Mayo Chair, Paul O'Brien IFA Environmental & Rural Affairs Chair

Specific Details: Requests for budgetary supports from Mayo County Councils’ Ballina Municipal District Council General Municipal Allocation (GMA) funding for Ballina Salmon Festival, Irelands oldest community festival along the Wild Atlantic Way, and economic driver of revenue to Co Mayo annual.
DPOs Lobbied: Jarlath Munnelly|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Annie May Reape|Councillor|Mayo County Council::John O'Hara|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Seamus Weir|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Mark Duffy|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Michael Loftus|Councillor|Mayo County Council
Subject Matter: Requests for budgetary supports from Mayo County Councils’ Ballina Municipal District Council General Municipal Allocation (GMA) funding for Ballina Salmon Festival, Irelands oldest community festival along the Wild Atlantic Way, and economic driver of revenue to Co Mayo annual.
Intended Results: Additional funding from Ballina Municipal Council GMA funding to ensure the financial return of Ballina Salmon Festival after a three-year absence due to Covid.
Lobbying Activities: Chairpersons of the festival made several calls to Ballina Municipal District Councillors requesting continued support for the festival, to ensure its financial return to Ballina and Co Mayo, after a three-year absence due to Covid. The festival delivers an annual revenue return of over €4 million to the economy of the county, in July every year.|Phone call|2-5

Specific Details: Meeting between Mayo County Council and Ballina Chamber with one of three Twin Town sister city representatives, with the aim of organising and planning for renewed links between Ballina Co Mayo and Pisstfield MA USA.  Email with representative from Scranton PA, USA.
DPOs Lobbied: Jarlath Munnelly|Councillor|Mayo County Council::John O'Hara|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Mark Duffy|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Annie May Reape|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Michael Loftus|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Seamus Weir|Councillor|Mayo County Council
Subject Matter: Meeting between Mayo County Council and Ballina Chamber with one of three Twin Town sister city representatives, with the aim of organising and planning for renewed links between Ballina Co Mayo and Pisstfield MA USA.  Email with representative from Scranton PA, USA.
Intended Results: Ensure the support of Mayo County Council's Ballina Municipal District Councillors, as Ballina Chamber aim to renew and strengthen links with twin towns of Ballina and the wider Co Mayo diaspora. Allocate funding for diaspora themed events in 2023 budget plans, as part of Ballina 2023 celebrations.
Lobbying Activities: Meetings with representatives from Ballina Twin Town Pittsfield MA USA, councillors and Ballina Chamber to ensure the financial supports of events planned as part Ballina 2023 diaspora celebrations, to be identified and included in Ballina Municipal District Council 2023 budgets.|Meeting|2-5::Email between representatives from Ballina Twin Town Scranton PA USA, and Pisstfield MA USA, Municipal councillors and Ballina Chamber to ensure the supports of events planned as part Ballina 2023 diaspora celebrations, to be identified and included in Ballina Municipal District Council 2023 budgets.|Email|2-5

Specific Details: Ballina Chamber met with five of six Ballina Municipal District Councillors to lobby for an expanded GMA funding in support of additional services provided by the Chamber, which include supporting four offices and two public toilets in the Mayo County Council owned building, which is managed by Ballina Chamber in respect of a Caretakers agreement.
DPOs Lobbied: John O'Hara|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Annie May Reape|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Mark Duffy|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Michael Loftus|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Seamus Weir|Councillor|Mayo County Council
Subject Matter: Ballina Chamber met with five of six Ballina Municipal District Councillors to lobby for an expanded GMA funding in support of additional services provided by the Chamber, which include supporting four offices and two public toilets in the Mayo County Council owned building, which is managed by Ballina Chamber in respect of a Caretakers agreement.
Intended Results: Highlight the additional services Ballina Chamber provide Ballina and North Mayo business community, and wider North Mayo community, as not currently known by the councillors. Advise the councillors on the rising overheads and costs of running the building, with no additional funds provided to do so.

Specific Details: Following on from a meeting with the council and announcement of GMA allocation, Ballina Chamber emailed Six Ballina Municipal District Councillors and two Mayo County Council staff to lobby for an expanded GMA funding in support of additional services provided by the Chamber, which include supporting four offices and two public toilets in the Mayo County Council owned building, which is managed by Ballina Chamber in respect of a Caretakers agreement.
DPOs Lobbied: Annie May Reape|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Jarlath Munnelly|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Seamus Weir|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Michael Loftus|Councillor|Mayo County Council::John O'Hara|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Mark Duffy|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Tom Gilligan|Director of Services or Equivalent|Mayo County Council::Declan Turnbull|Regional Services|Mayo County Council
Subject Matter: Following on from a meeting with the council and announcement of GMA allocation, Ballina Chamber emailed Six Ballina Municipal District Councillors and two Mayo County Council staff to lobby for an expanded GMA funding in support of additional services provided by the Chamber, which include supporting four offices and two public toilets in the Mayo County Council owned building, which is managed by Ballina Chamber in respect of a Caretakers agreement.
Intended Results: Following on from a meeting with councillors and announcement of GMA allocation, the aim was to highlight the additional services Ballina Chamber provide Ballina and North Mayo business community. The councillors were again advised about the rising overheads and costs of running the building and festival, with no additional funds provided to do so. The Chamber has lobbied for an enhanced GMA budget currently allocated to Ballina Chamber in respect of its activities.

Specific Details: Ballina delegation visits Scranton, PA USA and New York USA
DPOs Lobbied: Declan Turnbull|Regional Services|Mayo County Council::Annie May Reape|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Mark Duffy|Councillor|Mayo County Council
Subject Matter: Ballina delegation visits Scranton, PA USA and New York USA
Intended Results: Ballina Chamber was part of a Twin Town delegation to the USA in March specifically Scranton PA and New York USA. Ballina Chamber's goal was to ensure that Ballina and Co Mayo business community had a voice at these events, celebrating the Co Mayo diaspora and links with Ballina, North Mayo and the diaspora in Pennsylvania and New York.
Lobbying Activities:
Ballina Chamber attended a number of functions as part of a delegation from Ballina Municipal District Council and Mayo County Council, to the US which took place in March to coincide with St Patrick's Day celebrations. 
|Event / Reception|2-5

Specific Details: Mayo County Council - Enough is Enough Campaign
DPOs Lobbied: Al McDonnell|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Annie May Reape|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Blackie Gavin|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Brendan Mulroy|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Christy Hyland|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Cyril Burke|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Damien Ryan|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Donna Sheridan|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Ger Deere|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Gerry Coyle|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Gerry Murray|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Jarlath Munnelly|Councillor|Mayo County Council::John Caulfield|Councillor|Mayo County Council::John Cribbin|Councillor|Mayo County Council::John O'Hara|Councillor|Mayo County Council::John O'Malley|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Mark Duffy|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Martin McLoughlin|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Michael Burke|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Michael Kilcoyne|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Michael Loftus|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Michael Smyth|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Neil Cruise|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Patsy O'Brien|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Paul McNamara|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Peter Flynn|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Richard Finn|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Seamus Weir|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Sean Carey|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Tom Connolly|Councillor|Mayo County Council
Subject Matter: Mayo County Council - Enough is Enough Campaign
Intended Results: To voice farmers' anger and frustration at the ever-increasing administrative burden being placed on them which has had a major impact on farm family incomes.::These frustrations have broadened into anger with European and National lawmakers over the massive increase in regulations relating to Agriculture. The EU, the Irish Government and local Government are devising policies far from the farm gate with little or no consideration of the direct impact on farmers.::The following are some of the key issues that are contributing to growing frustration and anger with the political system::1. The transformation of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) away from supporting food production towards actually reducing farm output. The Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) funding is being redirected to environmental schemes – the EU is effectively implementing new environmental regulations such as the “eco-schemes” on the cheap by redirecting existing funding instead of allocating additional funds.::2. The failure of the EU to properly compensate farmers under the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP). In 2014, Ireland received €1.16bn in Pillar one funding from EU – that figure is effectively the same today, 10 years on, despite huge inflation in farmers' cost of production in the interim. Farmers are being asked to do much more to receive a lot less funds in real terms.::3. The proposed Mercusor trade deal being pushed by the European Commission has the capacity to devastate, in particular, the Irish beef sector. Europe is placing a massive amount of additional regulations on European farmers but, at the same time, is seeking to increase food imports from South America produced under much lower environmental rules with a higher carbon footprint.::4. Overly complicated schemes which have been poorly implemented by the Irish Department of Agriculture. This has contributed to widespread delays in payments, most notably the Agri-Climate Rural Environment Scheme (ACRES) scheme. Following a meeting between the Minister and IFA President Francie Gorman last week on foot of the Feb 1st protests, the Minister agreed to make an interim payment to all farmers.::However, this will only partly resolve the payments mess created by his own department. In addition, there are farmers still waiting to get into the scheme.::5. There has also been a complete systems failure on farm investment grant aid Targeted Agricultural Modernisation Scheme (TAMS) scheme. No approvals of note were granted under the scheme in 2023.::6. Farm schemes are now so complicated that agri consultants are threatening strike action as the feel they can no longer administrate these schemes designed by the Department of Agriculture effectively.::7. Reductions to the Nitrates derogation from 250kg organic N to 220kg organic N imposed by the European Commission with absolutely no flexibility offered. Furthermore, the Commission continue to threaten to remove it altogether in 2026.::8. The Nature Restoration Law which places further restrictions on farmers, particularly on designated lands with no compensation.::9. The Industrial Emissions Directive and the Commission's farcical handling of it. Their initial proposals would have seen c. 50% of Irish dairy farmers requiring an Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) license just to farm.::The current revised proposal excludes bovines but will still see a huge amount of additional pig and poultry farmers now requiring an Environmental Protection Agency (EPA license). The Commission's approach to classify farms under an “industrial” directive encapsulates their current lack of regard for farming.::10. The lack of flexibility being shown to tillage farmers within new regulations. No flexibility currently being offered to farmers who are struggling to meet the stipulated “3-crop rule” due to very difficult autumn weather conditions which massively limited autumn plantings.::11. Agricultural emissions which are not being measured fairly. There must be an accurate measurement of greenhouse gas emissions and carbon removals at farm level. It is imperative that any measurement of emissions and removals is based on research that reflects Irish conditions.::On-farm sequestration and biogenic methane from livestock, along with emissions and removals from Ireland's unique mineral and peat soils, must be based on peer reviewed trials in Ireland. On-farm measures such as anaerobic digestion and rooftop solar should count towards reducing emissions from the agricultural sector.::12. The shambolic management of Ireland's forestry policy which has led to farmers losing complete confidence in the forestry sector compounded by the refusal of the Department of Agriculture, Food, and the Marine (DAFM) to provide appropriate recompense for farmers impacted by Ash Dieback. The total amount of land planted for forestry in 2023 was 1,650ha, corresponding to the lowest annual planting rate since 1946.::To ask Mayo County Council to do their utmost to highlight the issues raised and seek a fundamental reset of how farm policy is devised and implemented both at the EU and in Ireland.::To ask that Mayo County Council approve the following resolution::Mayo County Council resolves to write to the President of the EU Commission, the Taoiseach and the Minister for Agriculture advising them that the Council has passed the following resolution. Mayo County Council supports the IFA ‘enough is enough' campaign.::The Council recognises the significant contribution that farming, and the Agri-sector makes to the Irish and local economy. The Council acknowledges the income challenge on Irish farmers arising from the significant increases in the cost of doing business, regulatory costs and cuts in Basic Income support for farmers.::The Council calls on the Government to introduce no further regulations on farmers or any measures that may increase costs on farms without full negotiation and agreement with the Irish Farmers Association (IFA). The Council calls on the European Union and the Irish Government to provide additional stand-alone funding, separate to the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), to support farmers to undertake climate and biodiversity measures.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: John Lynskey IFA Mayo County Chair
Grassroots directive: To protest outside local county council offices and lobby local Councillors on why farmers are saying Enough is Enough"."

Specific Details: Ballina Chamber launch of Local Election Manifesto 2024
DPOs Lobbied: Jarlath Munnelly|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Michael Loftus|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Annie May Reape|Councillor|Mayo County Council::Mark Duffy|Councillor|Mayo County Council::John O'Hara|Councillor|Mayo County Council
Subject Matter: Ballina Chamber launch of Local Election Manifesto 2024
Intended Results: Ballina Chamber unveiled its Local and EU Election Manifestos, urging candidates to adopt bold visions for Ballina’s long-term growth and prosperity. Ballina Chamber is emphasizing the need for ambitious strategies to address key challenges. Through the recent Chamber business survey ‘Raising the issues that matter to you – Ballina Chamber Members & Business Community, members have rasied many issues affecting their business and the long-term development of Ballina and North Mayo.
Lobbying Activities: Post on social media channels, appealing to sitting and current candidates running in the Local Elections, June 2024.  |Social Media|2-5
